msgSnippet: ... it, ... checks ... work ... it s ... work. The ... manual can ... Yes, it is true, but it is a hard assumption, because you need a third library to get
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...>
wrote:
>
> David wrote:
>
> > I have the following problem:
> >
> > I have a method that find a file on classpath and I want to test
it,
> > without assuming a particular classpath.
> >
> > My idea is to append on the classpath the System.getProperty
> > ("java.io.tmpdir") location, then create a temporary file and
checks
> > that a given file exist on my new classpath.
> >
> > Changing during execution the property: java.class.path doesn't
work
> > because such information even the value of the property change,
it's
> > value is not updated on the Virtual Machine.
> >
> > For sure I need in some way to use some ClassLoader trick but I
> > don't know how to do that.
>
> I imagine if you ran each test in its own class loader, that'd
work. The
> easiest way I know to do that is to run the tests from Ant and use
> fork="yes" so that each test runs in its own process. The Ant
manual can
> say more.
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.ca
> Your guide to software craftsmanship
> JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> 2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
>

Yes, it is true, but it is a hard assumption, because you need a
third library to get this behavior. A testing framework should
provide this case, without using another one library.

Thanks,

David
